articles.headline: Money Talks to Have Before Marriage
articles.snippet: Love may move mountains, but money can crumble the strongest marriage. A good way to head off problems is to discuss financial issues before the ceremony.
articles.abstract: Love may move mountains, but money can crumble the strongest marriage. A good way to head off problems is to discuss financial issues before the ceremony.
articles.lead_paragraph: Divorce tends to be emotionally gut-wrenching for the people who go through it (not to mention those around them). But most couples don’t realize that divorce can also be among the most ruinous financial moves anyone can make.

articles.headline: 65 and Up and Looking for Work
articles.snippet: Nearly half a million people 65 and older want to work but cannot find a job, this group’s highest unemployment level since the Great Depression.
articles.abstract: Nearly half a million people 65 and older want to work but cannot find a job, this group’s highest unemployment level since the Great Depression.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is well known that during the nation’s gale-force recession, many older Americans who dreamed of retirement continued to work, often because their 401(k)’s had plunged in value.

articles.headline: Witness in Galleon Case Is Said to Have History of Passing Secrets
articles.snippet: Roomy Khan faxed confidential sales and pricing information for computer chips sold by Intel to Galleon in 1998, according to court documents.
articles.abstract: Roomy Khan faxed confidential sales and pricing information for computer chips sold by Intel to Galleon in 1998, according to court documents.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  The central witness in a federal insider trading case against Raj Rajaratnam, founder of the Galleon hedge fund, has a more than 10-year history of passing on privileged information to the fund, according to federal court documents.
articles.byline: By Ashlee Vance and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Food Label Program to Suspend Operations
articles.snippet: The government is working on new regulations for food labeling after criticism of the Smart Choices campaign.
articles.abstract: The government is working on new regulations for food labeling after criticism of the Smart Choices campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: Under pressure from state and federal authorities who feared consumers would be misled, the food industry on Friday started backing away from a major labeling campaign meant to highlight the nutritional benefits of hundreds of products.

articles.headline: Short Memories at Goldman
articles.snippet: It is uncertain how much of the $16 billion Goldman Sachs has set aside for bonuses can be attributed to government assistance, but it has got to be a substantial amount, which leads to a question: Where’s our bonus?
articles.abstract: It is uncertain how much of the $16 billion Goldman Sachs has set aside for bonuses can be attributed to government assistance, but it has got to be a substantial amount, which leads to a question: Where’s our bonus?
articles.lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, shortly after Goldman Sachs reported its latest blowout quarter, the firm’s chief executive, Lloyd Blankfein, spoke at a Fortune magazine breakfast.

articles.headline: Arizona May Put State Prisons in Private Hands
articles.snippet: State officials will soon seek private bids for 9 of the state’s 10 prison complexes that house roughly 40,000 inmates, including 127 who are on death row.
articles.abstract: State officials will soon seek private bids for 9 of the state’s 10 prison complexes that house roughly 40,000 inmates, including 127 who are on death row.
articles.lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Ariz.  One of the newest residents on Arizona’s death row, a convicted serial killer named Dale Hausner, poked his head up from his television to look at several visitors strolling by, each of whom wore face masks and vests to protect against the sharp homemade objects that often are propelled from the cells of the condemned.

articles.headline: The Loin in Winter: Hefner Reflects, and Grins
articles.snippet: Hugh Hefner, now old enough to be the great-grandfather of some of his girlfriends, looks back at a cultural contribution that today seems almost quaint.
articles.abstract: Hugh Hefner, now old enough to be the great-grandfather of some of his girlfriends, looks back at a cultural contribution that today seems almost quaint.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Hugh Hefner leaned back on a red loveseat, the saggy one in the study of his infamous mansion here, and interlocked his fingers behind his head. A visitor had asked  more like shouted, since he has trouble hearing  a question about mortality.

articles.headline: Britons Weary of Surveillance in Minor Cases
articles.snippet: A local government’s investigation of a British family over a girl’s school application raised concerns about the usage of a 2000 surveillance law.
articles.abstract: A local government’s investigation of a British family over a girl’s school application raised concerns about the usage of a 2000 surveillance law.
articles.lead_paragraph: POOLE, England  It has become commonplace to call Britain a “surveillance society,” a place where security cameras lurk at every corner, giant databases keep track of intimate personal details and the government has extraordinary powers to intrude into citizens’ lives.

articles.headline: Small Business Faces Sharp Rise in Costs of Health Care
articles.snippet: As Congress nears votes on legislation that would overhaul the health care system, many small businesses say they are facing the steepest rise in insurance premiums they have seen in recent years.
articles.abstract: As Congress nears votes on legislation that would overhaul the health care system, many small businesses say they are facing the steepest rise in insurance premiums they have seen in recent years.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Congress nears votes on legislation that would overhaul the health care system, many small businesses say they are facing the steepest rise in insurance premiums they have seen in recent years.

articles.headline: Can Atlantic City Raise the Stakes?
articles.snippet: One gambling executive warns that Atlantic City faces a “death spiral,” and some think that the solution is to think big — and beyond gambling.
articles.abstract: One gambling executive warns that Atlantic City faces a “death spiral,” and some think that the solution is to think big — and beyond gambling.
articles.lead_paragraph: Atlantic City

articles.headline: Sony’s Version of Tracy and Hepburn
articles.snippet: At Sony Pictures Entertainment, a rare leadership structure for any industry: a man and a woman as equal partners at the helm.
articles.abstract: At Sony Pictures Entertainment, a rare leadership structure for any industry: a man and a woman as equal partners at the helm.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES

articles.headline: H1N1 Widespread in 46 States as Vaccines Lag
articles.snippet: President Obama’s decision to make the swine flu outbreak a national emergency lets hospitals and local governments set up alternate sites to handle patients if needed.
articles.abstract: President Obama’s decision to make the swine flu outbreak a national emergency lets hospitals and local governments set up alternate sites to handle patients if needed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama has declared the swine flu outbreak a national emergency, allowing hospitals and local governments to speedily set up alternate sites for treatment and triage procedures if needed to handle any surge of patients, the White House said on Saturday.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Donald G. McNeil Jr

articles.headline: Man’s World at White House? No Harm, No Foul, Aides Say
articles.snippet: President Obama called criticism over an all-male basketball game “bunk,” and points out that he is surrounded by strong women both at home and in his administration.
articles.abstract: President Obama called criticism over an all-male basketball game “bunk,” and points out that he is surrounded by strong women both at home and in his administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Does the White House feel like a frat house?

articles.headline: If Lenders Say ‘The Dog Ate Your Mortgage’
articles.snippet: Judges are scrutinizing the methods lenders have used in foreclosures. One ruling eliminated a mortgage debt because the lender didn’t prove it held the note.
articles.abstract: Judges are scrutinizing the methods lenders have used in foreclosures. One ruling eliminated a mortgage debt because the lender didn’t prove it held the note.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR decades, when troubled homeowners and banks battled over delinquent mortgages, it wasn’t a contest. Homes went into foreclosure, and lenders took control of the property.

articles.headline: Bombings in Iraq, Deadliest Since 2007, Raise Security Issue
articles.snippet: Sunday’s bombings, which killed over 155 people, poses a challenge to Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, whose popularity has rested on the belief that he has kept Iraq safe.
articles.abstract: Sunday’s bombings, which killed over 155 people, poses a challenge to Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki, whose popularity has rested on the belief that he has kept Iraq safe.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Two synchronized suicide car bombings struck at the heart of the Iraqi government here on Sunday, severely damaging the Justice Ministry and provincial council complexes, leaving a scene of carnage that raised new questions about the government’s ability to secure its most vital operations.

articles.headline: Investor With Madoff Is Found Dead in His Pool
articles.snippet: Jeffry Picower, a 67-year-old philanthropist, was one of the largest investors in Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.abstract: Jeffry Picower, a 67-year-old philanthropist, was one of the largest investors in Bernard L. Madoff’s Ponzi scheme.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeffry M. Picower, a prominent philanthropist accused of reaping about $7 billion in profit from Bernard L. Madoff’s vast Ponzi scheme, was found dead on Sunday afternoon in a swimming pool at his mansion in Palm Beach, Fla.

articles.headline: Salute All Cars, Kids. It’s a Rule in China.
articles.snippet: Skewering dubious edicts by local governments, like a rule that children must salute passing cars, has become a favorite pastime of China’s Web users.
articles.abstract: Skewering dubious edicts by local governments, like a rule that children must salute passing cars, has become a favorite pastime of China’s Web users.
articles.lead_paragraph: HUANGPING, China  All the students at Luolang Elementary School, a yellow-and-orange concrete structure off a winding mountain road in southern China, know the key rules: Do not run in the halls. Take your seat before the bell rings. Raise your hand to ask a question.

articles.headline: A Big Deal, but Not a Good One
articles.snippet: We haven’t seen anything quite like these Comcast-NBC Universal talks since the merger of Time Warner and AOL. And that turned out well, right?
articles.abstract: We haven’t seen anything quite like these Comcast-NBC Universal talks since the merger of Time Warner and AOL. And that turned out well, right?
articles.lead_paragraph: Content never became king  search did  but the notion continues to lure otherwise careful companies to the deal altar with its abundant charms.

articles.headline: Twitter Serves Up Ideas From Its Followers
articles.snippet: Twitter is “smart enough, or lucky enough” to let its users create new features for it, says an M.I.T. professor.
articles.abstract: Twitter is “smart enough, or lucky enough” to let its users create new features for it, says an M.I.T. professor.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Companies big and small monitor Twitter to find out what their customers like and what they want changed. Twitter does the same.

articles.headline: Online Rally May Sidestep Newspapers
articles.snippet: For many marketers, newspaper Web sites are valuable for special occasions but cheaper generic placement is better for everyday use.
articles.abstract: For many marketers, newspaper Web sites are valuable for special occasions but cheaper generic placement is better for everyday use.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a good day for newspaper Web sites when Mercedes-Benz USA introduced its updated E-Class cars this summer. Mercedes bought out the ad space on the home pages of The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal and The New York Times, and had those sites create special 3-D ads for them, at an estimated cost of $100,000 a site.

articles.headline: Studios’ Quest for Life After DVDs
articles.snippet: Hollywood used to keep quiet about digital video, for fear of angering DVD retailers like Wal-Mart. The silence is over, and the innovations are rolling out.
articles.abstract: Hollywood used to keep quiet about digital video, for fear of angering DVD retailers like Wal-Mart. The silence is over, and the innovations are rolling out.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Movie studios, desperate to return their home entertainment divisions to growth, are scrambling to shape the post-DVD era.

articles.headline: Recession Drives Surge in Youth Runaways
articles.snippet: As more families face economic hardships, experts have seen an increasing number of children leave home for life on the streets, including many under 13.
articles.abstract: As more families face economic hardships, experts have seen an increasing number of children leave home for life on the streets, including many under 13.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEDFORD, Ore.  Dressed in soaked green pajamas, Betty Snyder, 14, huddled under a cold drizzle at the city park as several older boys decided what to do with her.

articles.headline: Trying to Rein In ‘Too Big to Fail’ Institutions
articles.snippet: Congress and the White House will take up how to deal with companies so big the government must rescue them.
articles.abstract: Congress and the White House will take up how to deal with companies so big the government must rescue them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Congress and the Obama administration are about to take up one of the most fundamental issues stemming from the near collapse of the financial system last year  how to deal with institutions that are so big that the government has no choice but to rescue them when they get in trouble.

articles.headline: States Pressed Into New Role on Medical Marijuana
articles.snippet: Local officials are debating how to regulate medical marijuana after the Justice Department stepped back.
articles.abstract: Local officials are debating how to regulate medical marijuana after the Justice Department stepped back.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREELEY, Colo.  Health and law enforcement officials around the nation are scrambling to figure out how to regulate medical marijuana now that the federal government has decided it will no longer prosecute legal users or providers.
